text: Irritability.
Mood swings.
Bloating.

Nothing’s a bigger bummer than PMS symptoms,
but what causes them causes them and why?

Premenstrual syndrome, or PMS, is a grab-bag
of physical and psychological symptoms, including
depression, acne, cramps and fatigue and more.

Every woman's experience of PMS is different,
but about 75% of women suffer from at least
one PMS symptom each month.

Things are even tougher for the roughly 5%
of women with premenstrual dysphoric disorder.

These women experience extreme PMS symptoms
which can interfere with their work, social
lives and relationships.

Estrogen and progesterone are currently the
usual suspects behind these symptoms.

But scientists still don’t have enough evidence
to connect all the dots between hormones and
PMS.

It turns out that women who experience PMS,
and women who don’t, actually have the same

amount of progesterone and estrogen in their
blood.

The women experiencing PMS are probably just
more sensitive to the changes in these hormones
during the menstrual cycle.

And these changes can have big effects on
the brain and nervous system, which drives
your thoughts, emotions and behavior.

That could explain why PMS is associated with
mood swings and irritability as your hormones
are wreaking havoc on your body.

Scientists think that during PMS, changes
in hormones mess with two important chemicals

that cells use to chat with each other--serotonin
and GABA.

Serotonin’s important for lots of brain
functions, but we’re going to focus on its
leading role in affecting mood.

At the microscopic level, progesterone and
estrogen might change how much serotonin is
available to shuttle messages between cells.

Progesterone stimulates an enzyme that breaks
down serotonin, while estrogen may boost serotonin
by inhibiting this enzyme.

So when progesterone levels are high and estrogen
is low—like during that week before your
period—there’s less serotonin available.

And too little serotonin causes depression,
anxiety, food cravings and fatigue
But let’s get back to GABA.

GABA is super important in regulating stress,
anxiety, and alertness—basically, situations
where excitable neurons are firing.

GABA acts like a chill pill for these neurons,
calming them down so they fire less often.

Normally, when GABA nestles into its own personalized
receptors on neuron surfaces, it triggers

tiny channels to open across the neuron’s
membrane.

Chloride ions flow into the cell, and all
that negative charge keep the neuron from
firing.

Remember progesterone, one of the two PMS
suspects we mentioned earlier?

In the ovaries and the brain, progesterone
is broken down into metabolites like allopregnanolone,
aka ALLO.

When ALLO is around, it improves the ability
of GABA receptors to regulate mood.

Reductions in or increased tolerance to ALLO
are linked to higher stress and anxiety.

Women who want to avoid these symptoms sometimes
go on hormonal birth control, which smooths

out the cyclical changes that that can alter
ALLO and serotonin levels.

But what causes PMS symptoms outside of the
brain, like bloating and cramping and stomach
pain?

Scientists aren’t sure, but they think the
bloating could come from changes in a kidney
hormone that affects water retention.

And the pain could be a side-effect of all
those brain and mood changes that make you

extra-sensitive to sensations that you can
normally ignore.

It turns out that PMS might also be affected
by stuff outside your body, like foods you
eat or stress.

Scientists also suspect that cultural and
personal attitudes play a role, too—but

that’s a whole different story for another
day.
